importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The American Dialect Society named 'enshittification' as its Word of the Year in 2023, highlighting the widespread cultural and linguistic adoption of the term to describe the decline of internet platforms.
The article was published on October 21, 2025, in the Planet Money newsletter, marking a timely discussion on internet platform degradation in the current tech landscape.

importantTimeframes.approximateTimeFrameStart: Stage 1: Early growth phase of platforms
importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Doctorow outlines a three-stage model of platform degradation, beginning with user-friendly innovation (Stage 1), progressing to business-centric favoritism (Stage 2), and culminating in user and merchant harm (Stage 3).

keyTakeAways: Enshittification is a term coined by Cory Doctorow to describe the degradation of internet platforms into exploitative, profit-driven systems that prioritize shareholder returns over user and business welfare.

Platforms like Facebook, Google, Amazon, and Uber evolve from user-focused, network-effect-driven startups (Stage 1) to business-friendly, data-harvesting, and cost-subsidizing models (Stage 2), and finally to exploitative pricing, algorithmic manipulation, and user harm (Stage 3).

Amazon is cited as an example where sellers face 'junk fees' that erode margins, leading to price increases for consumers, and Facebook manipulates feeds to prioritize paid content over user preferences.
Doctorow attributes the decline to a lack of competition and weak consumer regulation, including the reliance on the consumer welfare standard in antitrust law.

Proposed solutions include stronger antitrust enforcement, 'right-to-exit' regulations (e.g., allowing users to take e-books with them), and promoting interoperability between platforms (e.g., allowing Android apps on iPhones, cross-platform messaging).
Amazon and Facebook have publicly rejected Doctorow’s claims, with Amazon calling them 'false and misleading' and Facebook not responding to inquiries.

namedEntities.name: Cory Doctorow
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Author, internet activist, and journalist who coined the term 'enshittification' and wrote the book titled 'Enshittification'.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Doctorow is the central intellectual force behind the theory of enshittification, providing the framework and evidence for how platforms degrade over time.

namedEntities.name: Enshittification
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A coined term describing the devolution of internet platforms from user-friendly services into exploitative, profit-maximizing systems.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The article centers on this concept as a diagnosis of platform behavior, particularly in major tech companies like Facebook, Amazon, and Uber.

namedEntities.name: Facebook (Meta)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A social media platform that Doctorow criticizes for manipulating user feeds and charging publishers for boosted content.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It serves as a primary example of enshittification in action, showing how user experience deteriorates due to algorithmic manipulation and ad-driven content feeding.

namedEntities.name: Amazon
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: E-commerce platform that Doctorow claims exploits merchants through junk fees, product cloning, and biased search algorithms.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Amazon is a key case study, illustrating how platform power leads to merchant losses and higher consumer prices through monopolistic practices.

namedEntities.name: Uber
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A ride-hailing platform mentioned as part of the broader category of companies undergoing enshittification.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Used as an example of how platforms evolve from user-friendly models to ones that prioritize profit over service quality and fairness.

namedEntities.name: Google
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A tech giant cited in the context of internet platform dynamics and data harvesting.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is included in the list of platforms experiencing enshittification, particularly in how it monetizes user data through targeted advertising.

namedEntities.name: American Dialect Society
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A society that named 'enshittification' Word of the Year in 2023.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This recognition underscores the cultural and linguistic significance of the term, indicating its broad acceptance in public discourse.

namedEntities.name: Merriam-Webster
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Dictionary publisher that included 'enshittification' in its dictionary despite its vulgar origin.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Demonstrates the term’s mainstream integration into language and public awareness, beyond just academic or niche use.

namedEntities.name: Institute for Local Self-Reliance
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A non-profit research and advocacy group cited by Doctorow as a source for Amazon fee data.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provides external validation of Doctorow’s claims about Amazon’s fee structures and their impact on sellers.

namedEntities.name: Planet Money
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A public radio show that published the article and discussed antitrust and tech regulation.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Acts as a platform for spreading the enshittification theory to a wider, informed audience and contributes to public discourse on platform governance.

namedEntities.name: Right-to-exit regulation
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A proposed policy allowing users to take their data or content with them when leaving a platform.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Serves as a concrete policy recommendation to counter enshittification by increasing user agency and platform accountability.

namedEntities.name: Interoperability
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A technical concept allowing different products or services to work together, as advocated by Doctorow.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Proposed as a solution to eliminate artificial monopolies and enable competition between platforms, such as allowing Android apps on iPhones or cross-platform messaging.

namedEntities.name: Consumer Welfare Standard
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A legal doctrine used in antitrust cases to judge whether companies are anti-competitive based on consumer harm, such as price increases.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Doctorow critiques this standard as insufficient, arguing it fails to address platform power and user exploitation beyond price changes.

namedEntities.name: Antitrust enforcement
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Government actions aimed at preventing monopolistic or anti-competitive behavior.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Doctorow calls for stronger antitrust enforcement to counter platform power and prevent enshittification.

namedEntities.name: Network Effects
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A phenomenon where a platform becomes more valuable as more users join it.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Used to explain how platforms lock in users, creating high switching costs and enabling long-term dominance.

namedEntities.name: Switching Costs
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The difficulty or cost users face when leaving a platform.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A key mechanism by which platforms maintain user loyalty and resist competition, central to enshittification.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article presents a theory developed by internet activist and author Cory Doctorow, titled 'Enshittification,' which describes how major internet platforms—such as Facebook, Google, Amazon, and Uber—evolve from user-centric startups into exploitative systems that harm both consumers and businesses. Doctorow outlines a three-stage model: in Stage 1, platforms grow rapidly and treat users fairly; in Stage 2, they prioritize business customers and begin harvesting data; and in Stage 3, they aggressively squeeze profits from users and merchants through manipulated algorithms, junk fees, and predatory pricing. The article argues that this degradation occurs due to a lack of competition and weak consumer regulation, particularly under the current consumer welfare standard in antitrust law. Doctorow proposes solutions including stronger antitrust enforcement, 'right-to-exit' regulations to allow users to take data with them, and greater interoperability between platforms to reduce monopolistic control. Amazon and Facebook have responded with denial, but the article highlights growing public and policy interest in reversing the trend of platform degradation.
title: A theory why the internet is going down the toilet
